items.title: Uber to deploy 20,000 Lucid Gravity robotaxis equipped with Nuro Driver, beginning next year [Video]
items.summary: Uber, Lucid Group, and Nuro, Inc. are partnering to deploy 20,000 Lucid Gravity robotaxis with Nuro Driver technology next year. This collaboration aims to provide a premium global robotaxi option on Uber's platform.

items.title: U.S. Video Surveillance Market to Reach $18.06 Billion by 2030
items.summary: The U.S. video surveillance market is projected to reach $18.06 billion by 2030, according to a new report. The market includes various components such as image sensors, cameras, encoders, and AI-based video management systems.

items.summary: BioNTech announced that Ryan Richardson will step down as Chief Strategy Officer in the Management Board on September 30, 2025.

items.title: Canada needs agency to manage public UFO sightings, says new federal report
items.summary: A new federal report in Canada recommends the creation of a government agency to manage public UFO sightings, emphasizing the need for a formal response system. This initiative aims to address the ethical implications of UFO reports and provide a structured approach to handling such phenomena.

items.title: Why giving 16-year-olds the vote could change UK politics forever
items.summary: Giving 16-year-olds the vote could change UK politics forever as young people historically vote for Labour, but this may not be the case in the future.

items.title: Why giving 16-year-olds the vote could change British politics forever
items.summary: Lowering the voting age to 16 could have a significant impact on British politics by shifting power towards the future generation who will have to live with the consequences. This decision could potentially change the political landscape in the UK.

items.title: Giving 16-year-olds the vote could change British politics forever

items.summary: Lowering the voting age to 16 will shift power towards the future and to the people who will have to live in it, changing British politics forever.

items.title: The voting age is dropping to 16 – here’s why it matters
items.summary: Lowering the voting age to 16 is seen as a way to give more power to the younger generation who will be most affected by future policies and decisions.

items.title: Intel's fancy new AI tool measures image quality in games in real time, so upscaling artifacts and visual nasties have nowhere to hide
items.summary: Intel's new AI tool is able to measure image quality in games in real time, effectively identifying upscaling artifacts and visual imperfections. This tool aims to quantify subjective aspects of image quality, providing a innovative solution for improving visual quality in gaming.

items.title: Intel, Indeed, Glassdoor Total 5,000+ Layoffs. Is Your Job AI-Proof?
items.summary: Intel, Indeed, and Glassdoor are cutting 5,000+ roles, raising concerns about the impact of AI on job security. Learn about the types of jobs being replaced by AI, why the layoffs are happening, and how to future-proof your career in the face of automation.

items.title: LoRA: Low-Rank Adaptation of Large Language Models Explained
items.summary: LoRA is a new technique for efficient fine-tuning of large language models by updating fewer parameters. It offers benefits such as faster adaptation, but also has limitations that need to be addressed. The research explores its real-world uses and potential for the future.

items.title: 'Sleeping With That Fear…': Perplexity CEO Aravind Srinivas On Staying Ahead In The AI Race
items.summary: Perplexity CEO Aravind Srinivas discusses how the fear of being copied drives innovation and success in the competitive AI industry.

items.title: Presentation: Making Augmented Reality Accessible: A Case Study of Lens in Maps
items.summary: Ohan Oda discusses making the Lens in Maps AR feature accessible to visually impaired users, sharing valuable lessons on designing inclusive AR experiences and the impact on users.

items.summary: Hackers have found new ways to hide malware in DNS records, exploiting the domain name system to conceal malicious code and prompt injection attacks against chatbots.

items.title: Quantum code breaking? You'd get further with an 8-bit computer, an abacus, and a dog
items.summary: Computer scientist Peter Gutmann criticizes quantum code breaking as 'bollocks' and suggests traditional methods may be more effective. The US National Institute for Standards and Technology has been advocating for post-quantum cryptographic algorithms since 2016.
